moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5
comment:
Nimzowitsch's forgotten idea for conducting this opening was revived by
Portisch (as Black) in his game with Andersson from Palma 1971.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6
comment:
An interesting position.
Black's normal strategy would be to storm forwards on the King side with his
mobile pawns, but the fact that White's KP is on e2 rather then e4 makes it
more difficult for Black to fix on a target. White's normal plan would be to
launch a Queen side advance with b2-b4, c4-c5 etc. breaking into Black's camp
at the sensitive point c7. However, the absence of White's KP from e4 also
exerts an influence over White's plan of campaign in that (after c4-c5) is QP
will be deprived of much of his support. In such strategically complex
position Numzowitsch excelled. Now many of his original ideas have been
absorbed into master tecnique or incorporated into "openings theory".

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3
comment:
A useful consolidating move directed against the mobility of
Black's KP and KBP. 14...

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5
comment:
Provocation. Also possible
was the more solipstic procedure Rf7,Qf8 followed by h7-h6 and g6-g5. But
Nimzowitsch prefers to encourage activity from his opponent since he correctly
perceives that this very activity will ultimately be White's undoing.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7
comment:
And prophylaxis! Observe the way in which Nimzowitsch guards the c7
point before it is attacked.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. Rfc1 h5
comment:
A device for gaining
space on the King side which is now regulation in the King's Indian Defence.
Given time Black will also play g6-g5 with an awesome array of pawns.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. Rfc1 h5 19. b4 axb4 20. axb4 Nd7 21. c5
comment:
This temporary sacrifice of a pawn looks most
promising since it exposes a number of weaknesses in the Black position.
However, with this move White is walking straight into a combinative ambush;
it could be said that he started out on the ambush trail when he was lured
into a Queen side advance (with gain of tempo) by 15...Nc5, but what other
choice did White have? Black holds the initiative on the King wing so the only
alternative to Queen side activity would be passive defence. Attractive though
its execution might appear Nimzowitsch had prepared so efficiently for the
possibility of a White Queen side advance that the whole plan of carrying it
through could be classed as a collective error.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. Rfc1 h5 19. b4 axb4 20. axb4 Nd7 21. c5 dxc5 22. bxc5 Nxc5 23. Bxc5 bxc5
comment: White has had to weaken his dark squares in order to shatter Black's pawns.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. Rfc1 h5 19. b4 axb4 20. axb4 Nd7 21. c5 dxc5 22. bxc5 Nxc5 23. Bxc5 bxc5 24. Rb5
comment:
"White seems to be in the ascendant but Black has not been marking
time. In fact he has been engaged in the accumulation of attacking energy (QR
file, h6-d2 diagonal, mobile pawn mass, etc.) and now emerges with a series of
noxious blows which had completely escaped White's attention. We might add, by
the way, that without Black's cooperation (the partly superfluous and partly
provocatory Nc5) White would scarcely ever have been able to arrange his
break-through with pawn-c5. (Nimzowitsch)

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. Rfc1 h5 19. b4 axb4 20. axb4 Nd7 21. c5 dxc5 22. bxc5 Nxc5 23. Bxc5 bxc5 24. Rb5 Bh6 25. f4 exf4 26. gxf4 c4
comment:
The ambush is spung and events now
develop by force. This counter-sacrifice has the effect of galvanising Black's
entire army which had hitherto slumbered peacefully within the confines of the
back two ranks.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. Rfc1 h5 19. b4 axb4 20. axb4 Nd7 21. c5 dxc5 22. bxc5 Nxc5 23. Bxc5 bxc5 24. Rb5 Bh6 25. f4 exf4 26. gxf4 c4 27. Rxc4 Ra1+ 28. Rc1 Qa3 29. Rbb1 Ra2 30. Rc2 Rxc2 31. Qxc2 Bxf4
comment:
The final point of the cpmbination. Black wins a
pawn and bares the white King. It was also possible to play 31...Bf8,
retaining the Bishop for attacking purposes, when White could hardly resist
successfully, so disorganised are his lines of defence (backward KP, straying
QP, exposed KBP and unsheltered K).

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. Rfc1 h5 19. b4 axb4 20. axb4 Nd7 21. c5 dxc5 22. bxc5 Nxc5 23. Bxc5 bxc5 24. Rb5 Bh6 25. f4 exf4 26. gxf4 c4 27. Rxc4 Ra1+ 28. Rc1 Qa3 29. Rbb1 Ra2 30. Rc2 Rxc2 31. Qxc2 Bxf4 32. Nxf4 Qe3+ 33. Kg2 Qxf4
comment:
An extra pawn
plus the more secure position should amount to a verdict of -+, but...

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. Rfc1 h5 19. b4 axb4 20. axb4 Nd7 21. c5 dxc5 22. bxc5 Nxc5 23. Bxc5 bxc5 24. Rb5 Bh6 25. f4 exf4 26. gxf4 c4 27. Rxc4 Ra1+ 28. Rc1 Qa3 29. Rbb1 Ra2 30. Rc2 Rxc2 31. Qxc2 Bxf4 32. Nxf4 Qe3+ 33. Kg2 Qxf4 34. Rb8+ Kh7 35. Qc3 Rg7 36. Re8 h4 37. Qf3 Qd4 38. e4
comment:
Nimzowitsch admitted quite frankly in his notes that he had forgotten that
this move was legal! White's counter-attack against Black's KBP and KRP forces
Nimzowitsch to start all over again. 38...

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. Rfc1 h5 19. b4 axb4 20. axb4 Nd7 21. c5 dxc5 22. bxc5 Nxc5 23. Bxc5 bxc5 24. Rb5 Bh6 25. f4 exf4 26. gxf4 c4 27. Rxc4 Ra1+ 28. Rc1 Qa3 29. Rbb1 Ra2 30. Rc2 Rxc2 31. Qxc2 Bxf4 32. Nxf4 Qe3+ 33. Kg2 Qxf4 34. Rb8+ Kh7 35. Qc3 Rg7 36. Re8 h4 37. Qf3 Qd4 38. e4 Qa4 39. Re6 Rf7 40. Kh3 Qc2 41. Qf4 Qc3+ 42. Kxh4 Qg7 43. Kg3 g5 44. Qe5 f4+ 45. Kf2 Qxe5 46. Rxe5 Kg6
comment:
Can Black win this position? The disappoinment of not having won already, plus
the fact that this position is a dead draw (after 47.h2-h3) might have caused
many masters to abandon the struggle and sue for peace, but there is one
possibility left.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. comment: The final shot in Black's arsenal.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. c4 b6 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 5. O-O O-O 6. Nc3 Bb7 7. d4 Ne4 8. Nxe4 Bxe4 9. d5 e5 10. Be3 f5 11. Ne1 Bxg2 12. Nxg2 d6 13. Qd2 Nd7 14. f3 a5 15. Rab1 Nc5 16. b3 Rf7 17. a3 Qf8 18. comment: And Black's passed pawns are the more powerful.
